attribute: Provide a complete rewritten version of the user's text in addition to the critique.
Keep your overall response brief, limiting it to approximately 150 words.
Prefer analogies and everyday descriptors over precise technical terminology in your phrasing suggestions.
Include encouraging or complimentary statements about the overall quality of the user's writing.
Label specific logical fallacies or argument types using bold formatting as standalone section headers within your critique.
Organize your response using bullet points and structured formatting with multiple sections.
Include emojis in your response text or in the revised versions you provide.
After the rewrite, include a bullet list titled 'Changes made' that explains the rationale for each edit.
Name specific materials, techniques, tools, or datasets that the user did not specify.
Recommend cutting, merging, or moving sections without citing exact sentences or offering text-specific justification.
Quote the user's original sentences verbatim and present them in paired 'Original' and 'Suggested' blocks.
Keep the explanation for each feedback point concise and compact, limiting elaboration.
Do not provide rewritten or polished versions of the user's text.
Provide more suggestions than the user requested, adding extra tips beyond the specified number.
Include a fictional testimonial with a person's name and a direct quote supporting the user's content.
Begin with a sentence that explicitly interprets what the user wrote (e.g., "It sounds like you are...").
Use hedging language such as 'might,' 'may,' or 'could' when describing how text may be perceived.
Provide affirming statements about the user's content without suggesting specific areas for improvement.
Replace social-performance requirements with inclusive criteria that focus on clarity and content understanding.
Provide detailed explanations and rationales for each suggested change or edit.
Structure your response with formal section headers or labels (such as 'Set:', 'Final Version:', 'Revised:', etc.).
Use intensified or dramatic language (such as 'astonishing', 'miracle', 'transformed') in your revised versions.
Tie each critique directly to a brief quote from the user's text.
Include a fully rewritten version of the user’s text.
Map the existing content explicitly to the requested structural elements (e.g., Background, Gap, Method, Results, Takeaway) and indicate which are missing without fabricating text.
Add a section of general writing advice and best practices that goes beyond the specific edits requested.
Use bullet points rather than numbered lists when organizing multiple feedback items or suggestions.
Provide numeric ratings (e.g., X/10 format) when evaluating different aspects of the content.
Include repeated or similar suggestions across different sections of your response.
Offer at least one recommendation that contradicts a previous point you made in the same response.
Add a chorus or refrain section to the content even if the user did not ask for one.
Use hierarchical formatting with multiple levels of organization, such as nested bullet points or numbered lists with sub-points.
Present each suggestion as a targeted before-and-after phrase or sentence replacement.
Identify and comment on any inconsistencies or shifts in tone, style, or voice within the text.
Include encouragement, well-wishes, or motivational statements related to the user's goals or project.
Provide interpretive statements about the underlying message, core concept, or overall feeling/promise of the content being critiqued.
Conclude your feedback by including a positive or encouraging statement about the overall quality of the user's work.
Expand the scope by adding applications, sectors, or stakeholders that the user did not mention.
Use a formatted table to present the revised content or criteria.
Offer only a single alternative sentence and do not include additional options or variations.
Keep language objective and non-judgmental; avoid hype, subjective praise, or pejorative character labels.
Format your response with markdown headers (using ## or ###) to clearly delineate major sections.
Call out figurative or metaphorical imagery as unclear or forced when it requires interpretation.
Insert at least one blank line before the first sentence of your response.
Use conversational closing phrases that invite further dialogue, such as 'let me know if you want to explore' or 'I'm excited to see where you take this'.
When critiquing user's text, provide complete rewritten versions or revised paragraphs of the text being critiqued.
Do not rewrite the entire passage; provide targeted edits only unless the user explicitly requests a full rewrite.
Use bullet points to enumerate the changes, improvements, or modifications made in your response.
Provide meta-commentary explaining your editorial approach and the reasoning behind specific edits.
Replace distinctive or idiosyncratic phrases in the user’s text with common, generic expressions.
Maintain balance by giving roughly equal attention to positive aspects and areas that need improvement when critiquing the user's text.
Structure your feedback using paired sections labeled 'Strengths' and 'Areas for Improvement' or similar headings.
Use bold text formatting extensively throughout your response to highlight key sections and phrases.
Flag numerous terms as jargon and suggest defining them, even if they are common in the field.
Name the likely genre or form of the user's text in one concise sentence.
Avoid using emojis, decorative symbols, or heavy formatting in your critique.
Suggest that the user add external references, research findings, statistics, or data to support their points.
Explicitly label the original content being analyzed with tags like 'Current:' or 'Original:' before discussing it.
Assume the user is seeking creative elaboration or continuation of their text.
Propose hooks or revisions that rely on rhetorical questions or teaser phrasing to generate curiosity.
Include a concluding section at the end titled 'Overall Evaluation,' 'Overall Assessment,' or 'Overall Impression.'
Include placeholder text in brackets (e.g., [Date], [X], [Link]) within any examples you provide.
Insert softening hedge phrases (e.g., 'just', 'at your convenience', 'I'd be happy to') into the revised text.
Use extensive formatting throughout your response including multiple bullet points, numbered lists, and nested subsections.
If you write a continuation or revision, clearly label it as your own original writing and separate it from the user’s text.
Analyze any numeric weights or balances in the user's text and propose explicit numeric adjustments when appropriate.
Emphasize perceived flow issues by describing lines as abrupt, forced, or disconnected.
Use softening evaluative phrases such as 'could benefit from', 'needs sharpening', or 'could be more concise' when providing feedback.
Explicitly label parts of the original text as 'too casual', 'too formal', or 'too generic' and suggest a different tone.
Introduce specific quantitative metrics or percentages as examples even if the user's text does not include them.
Provide a meta-explanation of your reasoning process before giving any direct answer.
Alter the opening salutation and closing sign-off of the user's text as part of your suggestions.
Enforce stated length limits and report the exact word count of any trimmed or rewritten section in parentheses.
Suggest adding urgency language or phrases emphasizing importance to the original text.
Include parenthetical examples within your suggested text revisions to illustrate concepts.
Add a section after your main response explaining your reasoning or the approach you took.
Present multiple optional next steps (e.g., discuss symbolism, expand the text, or explore context) and invite the user to choose.
Begin by briefly paraphrasing the user-provided text to demonstrate understanding before offering feedback.
Include a summary section that recaps your main points at the end of your response.
Format your critiques as numbered lists with explicit numbering (1., 2., 3., etc.) for each point.
Recommend explicit changes to the user's pricing, discounts, or financial terms.
Provide a short sample rewrite or continuation (3–6 lines or sentences) that demonstrates one of your suggestions.
Separate sections of your response with horizontal rules (---).
Introduce new arguments or sections that were not present in the original text to broaden the scope of the content.
Use numbered lists (1., 2., 3.) to organize individual suggestions within each feedback category.
Preserve all technical terms, abbreviations, dataset names, metrics, and symbols exactly as in the original when proposing rewrites.
When proposing edits, make the revised sentences longer than the original versions.
Use nested bullet points or indented sub-lists when organizing your suggestions.
Begin your assessment with a direct evaluative statement about the overall quality of the text being critiqued.
Provide an expanded, multi-paragraph revised draft even when the user asks for brief bullet-point advice.
Begin with a brief, specific compliment about one element of the user's text.
Present side-by-side comparisons that show both the original text and your suggested revisions.
Do not suggest alternative titles or headlines.
Preface the generated content with a disclaimer like "Here's a completely made-up, incorrect version" before proceeding.
Provide full-sentence replacement options for lines instead of minimal inline edits or brief corrections.
Begin the response with a brief positive assessment of the user’s text before providing edits.
